item.title: Article | Lego: can this most analogue of toys really be a modern urban planning tool?
item.dc:creator: arielnoyman
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row][vc_column][thb_image animation="animation fade-in" image="347" img_link="url:https%3A%2F%2Fwww.themarker.com%2Frealestate%2F1.4456551||target:%20_blank|"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/4"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][thb_gap height="20"][vc_btn title="Click here to read full article" style="outline" shape="square" color="black" align="center" i_icon_fontawesome="fa fa-newspaper-o" button_block="true" add_icon="true" link="url:http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theguardian.com%2Fcities%2F2014%2Fdec%2F18%2Flego-toys-urban-planning-tool-architects-mit||target:%20_blank|"][thb_gap height="20"][vc_column_text]

Lego: can this most analogue of toys really be a modern urban planning tool?

"...The answer might be found in Cambridge, Massachusetts, where MIT’s CityScope has created what managing director Ryan Chin calls an “urban observatory”. It’s a 30x60in Lego model of the city’s Kendall Square, on to which research scientists project digital data. For example, geolocated Twitter feeds from people working and studying in the real Kendall Square are mapped on to buildings; traffic information is projected on the brick roads. The idea, explains Chin, is to get a sense of how people live and work in the city. “We can look at flows of traffic, goods and people, and flows of energy,” he says. “What are the passive solar gains on a building? What are the shadows cast from a building on to a roadway?” Details about household sizes, population numbers and walkability can be programmed to provide, as he puts it, “a finely grained geospatial view of where things are happening in cities”.[/vc_column_text][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/4"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: Talk | City Science Summit
item.dc:creator: arielnoyman
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row][vc_column width="1/4"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][thb_gap height="20"][vc_column_text]

CityScope presentation | Ariel Noyman

The first City Science Summit organized by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in Andorra tackled several challenges related to urban planning, mobility and energy efficiency. All this with the aim of putting together proposals that help to draw up better planning for the cities of the future. As for the participation of professionals, 19 speakers from cities such as Hamburg, Helsinki, Boston, Shanghai and Taipei, along with Andorran experts have been the main protagonists of the City Science Summit.[/vc_column_text][thb_gap height="20"][vc_video link="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q4pTZjiL-Dc"][thb_gap height="20"][vc_btn title="Click here to read full article" style="outline" shape="square" color="black" align="center" i_icon_fontawesome="fa fa-newspaper-o" button_block="true" add_icon="true" link="url:http%3A%2F%2Fwww.actua.ad%2Fen%2Fnews%2Ffirst-mit-city-science-summit-held-andorra-closed-surpassing-participation-expectations||target:%20_blank|"][thb_gap height="20"][thb_image animation="animation fade-in" image="578" img_link="url:https%3A%2F%2Fwww.themarker.com%2Frealestate%2F1.4456551||target:%20_blank|"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/4"][thb_gap height="100"][/vc_column][/vc_row]
